results.snippet: By The Associated Press Democrats in New Mexico are voting to pick a candidate today to oppose Senator Harrison Schmitt, the former astronaut, in November, while Republicans in West Virginia are expected to nominate a strong conservative challenger...
results.lead_paragraph: By The Associated Press Democrats in New Mexico are voting to pick a candidate today to oppose Senator Harrison Schmitt, the former astronaut, in November, while Republicans in West Virginia are expected to nominate a strong conservative challenger to Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Minority Leader, who is unopposed in the Democratic primary as he seeks his fifth term. In other primary voting today, Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, faces two opponents in his bid for party renomination; two Democrats will vie in South Dakota to become the nominee against Governor William J. Janklow, a Republican, and both parties will nominate candidates for the governorship in New Mexico, where Bruce King, the Democratic incumbent, is prevented by state law from seeking re-election. New Mexico, West Virginia and South Dakota have Congressional primaries, but in Mississippi the balloting for the House of Representatives was delayed because the Justice Department has not accepted the state redistricting plan.

headline.main: RE-CREATING THE DAWN OF MANNED SPACE FLIGHT

results.snippet: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Audie Bock's most recent publication is a translation of the Japanese film director Akira Kurosawa's memoirs, ''Something Like an Autobiography'' (Alfred A. Knopf, May 1982). By...
results.lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Audie Bock's most recent publication is a translation of the Japanese film director Akira Kurosawa's memoirs, ''Something Like an Autobiography'' (Alfred A. Knopf, May 1982). By AUDIE BOCK HAMILTON AIR FORCE BASE, CALIF. An imposing multiple gateway yawns open, guardless. The driveway, lined with squat, thick-crowned old palm trees, curves lazily past large blocks of buildings painted a creamy military hue. Surrounding them are overlush lawns, the recent floodgauge Northern California rains pushing their seedy tips into a waist-deep jungle. A filling station sign sports the elongated lettering that immediately recalls late 1950's graphic design. No one walks the street, and the classic Chevy Bel Aires and Studebakers one would almost expect to roll by fail to materialize. A closer look reveals that many windows are broken or boarded over, and as the outlying aircraft hangars come into view, the roads and sidewalks bear those same waist-high grasses growing up through cracks in the asphalt and concrete. Hamilton lies deserted, a ghost of the cold war, built about the time the Soviets launched the satellite that started the space race, Sputnik I, in October 1957.

headline.main: Spacesuits Loaded on Shuttle As Preflight Work Continues

results.snippet: Astronaut spacesuits were loaded aboard the space shuttle Columbia today as preparations continued to start the five-day countdown next Tuesday.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronaut spacesuits were loaded aboard the space shuttle Columbia today as preparations continued to start the five-day countdown next Tuesday.

headline.main: FRENCH-SOVIET CREW BEGINS SPACE MISSION TODAY

results.snippet: If all goes well, a 43-year-old French Air Force colonel, Jean-Loup Chretien, will ride a Soviet rocket into earth orbit Thursday with two Russians, thus becoming the first astronaut to fly in space who is neither an American nor a citizen of a...

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: If all goes well, a 43-year-old French Air Force colonel, Jean-Loup Chretien, will ride a Soviet rocket into earth orbit Thursday with two Russians, thus becoming the first astronaut to fly in space who is neither an American nor a citizen of a Communist nation. For Colonel Chretien, a Breton-born fighter pilot, successful completion of the eight-day flight will mean a place alongside such heroes of French aviation as Louis Bleriot, who in 1909 piloted the first airplane to cross the English Channel. But the culmination of the 21-months he spent at Star City, the Soviet astronauts' training center on the northeast outskirts of Moscow comes at a time of chill in French-Soviet relations, and the political atmosphere has clouded what both nations originally envisioned as a celebration of detente. The schedule calls for the dart-shaped rocket to blast off from the Baikonur space launching center in the desert outside the city of Leninsk in Kazakhstan at 8:29 P.M., Moscow time, placing the Soyuz-T 6 spaceship into orbit 185 miles above the Earth. On Friday, the craft is scheduled to rendezvous and dock with the Salyut 7 orbiting laboratory in which two other Soviet astronauts have been working for six weeks.

headline.main: RIVALS LINE UP TRAILERS FOR 1984 SPOT

results.snippet: Like the tents of rival champions at the royal joust, the private office trailers of the Presidential aspirants sit backstage on wheels, ready for the first signs of Democratic battle in the morning.   Three 12-by-16-foot aluminum-skinned wagons,...

byline.original: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Like the tents of rival champions at the royal joust, the private office trailers of the Presidential aspirants sit backstage on wheels, ready for the first signs of Democratic battle in the morning. Three 12-by-16-foot aluminum-skinned wagons, separate homes for the Kennedy, Cranston and Glenn camps, are set side by side, with windows shut and blinds drawn, a temporary indoor neighborhood of inevitable rivalries, all waiting just beyond the bunting and television spotlights of the arena. Even before the first speech of the party conference, the trailers were busy today pumping hot air into the cavernous debating hall from their separate air conditioners. Political aides worked inside on paper strategies, preparing lists of the party delegates who will be wooed in the trailers for the next two days. Delegates will be cajoled by means of a flattering invitation to step off the convention floor and be greeted at the trailer door by the undeclared candidate who then might offer light refreshment and maybe even a willingness to listen at this early campaign point.

headline.main: FRENCHMAN BECOMES A SPACE PIONEER AT LAUNCHING OF SOVIET ROCKET

results.snippet: Invoking the words ''liberte, egalite, fraternite'' as the countdown clock neared zero, a 43-year-old French Air Force colonel, Jean-Loup Chretien, blasted into orbit aboard a Soviet rocket today and became the first astronaut who is neither an...

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Invoking the words ''liberte, egalite, fraternite'' as the countdown clock neared zero, a 43-year-old French Air Force colonel, Jean-Loup Chretien, blasted into orbit aboard a Soviet rocket today and became the first astronaut who is neither an American nor a citizen of a Communist nation to fly in space. For the first time since the Apollo-Soyuz flight that linked Soviet and American spacecraft seven years ago, Soviet television relayed live coverage of the liftoff. Millions of people here and in Western Europe watched the 300-ton rocket, painted red, white and blue, ride a fireball of exhaust into the night sky from the Baikonur launching center, outside the city of Leninsk in Kazakhstan, on the first stage of its journey to an orbit 185 miles high. Liftoff came precisely as scheduled, at 8:29 P.M. Moscow time (12:29 this afternoon, New York time). Black and white shots from a camera aboard the Soyuz T-6 spacecraft relayed from the first moments of flight showed Colonel Chretien and his companions, Col. Vladimir A. Dzhanibekov, the mission commander, and Aleksandr S. Ivanchenkov, the flight engineer, sitting in their flight couches and scanning the instruments.

results.snippet: International The P.L.O. is finished in Lebanon, according to a faction leader who has been the main leftist ally of the Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut. Walid Jumblat, a leader of the Druse, told reporters that the guerrilla group ''is outdated -...
results.lead_paragraph: International The P.L.O. is finished in Lebanon, according to a faction leader who has been the main leftist ally of the Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut. Walid Jumblat, a leader of the Druse, told reporters that the guerrilla group ''is outdated - it is over.'' In the fighting, Israeli jets continued attacking the positions of the Palestinian guerrillas trapped in Beirut. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The evacuation of hundreds of Americans and Lebanese with American immigration papers was carried out by a transport ship of the Sixth Fleet hours after the American Embassy in Beirut closed. At the 11th hour, scores of other Americans, Lebanese and Western Europeans arrived at the docks in the Mediterranean port of Junieh and were also taken aboard. (A1:3-5.)

headline.main: RUSSIANS UNVEIL MODERNIZED SPACE CONTROL CENTER

results.snippet: When a former French fighter pilot accompanied two Soviet astronauts into earth orbit this week and became the first Western European to fly in space, the Kremlin notched a small propaganda victory for a manned space program that has been lagging...

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: When a former French fighter pilot accompanied two Soviet astronauts into earth orbit this week and became the first Western European to fly in space, the Kremlin notched a small propaganda victory for a manned space program that has been lagging badly behind the spectacular missions mounted by the United States. By no coincidence, the Soyuz-Salyut flight of Col. Jean-Loup Chretien has also marked the international debut of an impressive new mission control center outside Moscow. After a 10-month renovation that cost 30 million rubles, the equivalent of $41 million at the official rate of exchange, the center reopened last month just in time for the launching of the two-man Soviet crew that preceded Colonel Chretien and his Soviet partners to the Salyut 7 orbital laboratory. Glimpses of the new center were shown on Soviet television after the May 13 Salyut launching, but the full unveiling of the complex came with the liftoff Friday of the Soyuz-T 6 craft that carried Colonel Chretien, Col. Vladimir A. Dzhanibekov and Aleksandr S. Ivanchenkov. With millions of Western Europeans watching the first Soviet liftoff to be televised live since the Soyuz-Apollo mission in 1975, the managers of the Soviet program were evidently eager to give as good a show as any that European audiences have seen from Cape Canaveral and Houston.

headline.main: SHUTTLE, CARRYING MILITARY CARGO, BLASTS OFF IN SMOOTHEST START YET

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia rocketed back into space today carrying its first military and commercial payloads and seeking to establish the re-usable spaceship's credentials for regular orbital operations.   The Columbia rose from the launching pad...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia rocketed back into space today carrying its first military and commercial payloads and seeking to establish the re-usable spaceship's credentials for regular orbital operations. The Columbia rose from the launching pad on time for the first time, a few microseconds before 11 A.M., New York time, bound for a planned week of circling the Earth. It is the spaceship's fourth and final test mission. Thunderclaps from the rockets reverberated through the humid air, the ground trembled and eventually the spaceship disappeared in its own vapor trail. The astronauts, Capt. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy and Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., were on their way to a 185-milehigh orbit, the highest thus far attained by the shuttle.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE'S ASTRONAUTS HAVE HAD A SHARE OF EARTHBOUND FRUSTRATIONS

results.snippet: Henry Warren Hartsfield Jr. is known as a patient man, but his patience has been tried by the length of time he has had to wait to travel beyond the earth's atmosphere.   He joined the Air Force astronaut program in 1966, later transferring to the...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Henry Warren Hartsfield Jr. is known as a patient man, but his patience has been tried by the length of time he has had to wait to travel beyond the earth's atmosphere. He joined the Air Force astronaut program in 1966, later transferring to the space agency. He has had to wait 16 years for his ride aboard the space shuttle Columbia. In that period, he has watched the development of the space program and observed as his colleagues took the voyages he would have given almost anything to be on.

results.snippet: The Columbia's astronauts, in their first full day of orbiting the earth, today began an experiment that could lead to the manufacture of medical products in space. This marked the first use of the space shuttle by American business.   But the...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Columbia's astronauts, in their first full day of orbiting the earth, today began an experiment that could lead to the manufacture of medical products in space. This marked the first use of the space shuttle by American business. But the astronauts, Capt. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy and Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., also had their hands full dealing with a rash of malfunctions, including their failure so far to activate the ''getaway special'' experiments by Utah State University students. Somehow the astronauts' commands are not reaching the experiment canister in the cargo bay.
